title: Canadian Disaster Database (2000-2012)
name: Canadian Disaster Database (2000-2012)
description: The Canadian Disaster Database contains detailed disaster information on natural, technological and conflict events (excluding war) that have directly affected Canadians since 1900

properties.name: Avalanche : Western Canada
properties.description: Golden, Fernie, Valemount, Nelson, Revelstoke, Durrand Glacier BC and Rogers Pass, Connaught Creek Valley, Okotoks, Mt. Terry Fox, Lake Louise, Rocky Mountains AB, January â€“ April 2003.  Deadly avalanche season since 1970 claimed 30 lives in Western Canada.  The higher death toll was in part due to unusual weather patterns brought by an El Nino winter.

properties.name: Rioting : Vancouver BC
properties.description: Vancouver BC, June 15 to 16, 2011. Following the loss of game seven in the Stanley Cup finals to the Boston Bruins, Vancouver Canucks fans took to the streets and rioting ensued. 140 people were taken to hospital with minor injuries while four people sustained serious injuries. Businesses in the Robson St./West Georgia St. were damaged (smashed windows, looting, and vandalism) while cars nearby were set on fire.

properties.name: Drought : Across Canada, concentrated in Saskatchewan and Alberta
properties.description: Across Canada, concentrated in Saskatchewan and Alberta, Spring 2001 to Fall 2002.  A severe drought was felt across all Canada, affecting 41,000 people, with the most devastating impacts felt in Saskatchewan and Alberta.  Record to near-record drought, as indicated by the Palmer Drought Severity Index, was recorded at several climate stations in 2001.  The winter of 2001-2002 continued the dry trend and brought above normal temperatures.  Fall 2002 brought much needed precipitation to relieve much of the drought, though dry conditions did remain in places.  The repercussions of the drought included agricultural production, employment, crop and livestock production, and the Gross Domestic Product.

properties.name: Drought : Saskatchewan and Alberta
properties.description: Saskatchewan and Alberta, March 2009.  The Canadian Wheat Board projected lower crop prospects by 20 per cent across the Prairies. A dozen counties and municipal districts in Alberta declared a state of drought emergency or disaster.  For example, Saskatoon had less than one-quarter of the usual amount of spring precipitation, making the months of March, April and May the driest since record-keeping began in 1892. It wasn't just spring that was dry. The soil moisture recharge period between September 1, 2008 and March 31, 2009 had less than 60 per cent of normal precipitation. To the west, in Alberta, conditions were even drier, as illustrated by precipitation amounts in Edmonton, where the 12- month total rain and snow from July 2008 to June 2009 was only 234 mm, less than half of normal and the driest such period with records dating back to 1880. Making matters worse, eight of the last ten years in Alberta's capital of Edmonton had less rain and snow than the 30-year average total, but no year was as scanty as the most recent. Not surprisingly, the flow of the North Saskatchewan River was at its third lowest level in nearly a century.

properties.name: Non-Residential : Toronto ON
properties.description: Toronto ON, August 10, 2008. A series of explosions at North York's Sunrise Propane Industrial Gases plant forced 12,000 people living inside a 1.6km radius to leave the area. A 25-year veteran of the Toronto fire service was killed while on duty in the aftermath of the explosions.

properties.name: Non-Residential : Brookdale MB
properties.description: Brookdale MB, April 14, 2002.  A rupture occurred on the 914-mm natural gas transmission Line 100-3 (main line) of TransCanada Pipelines 2 km from the village of Brookdale, Manitoba.  There were no injuries, damage or fatalities noted in the area. Approximately 100 people within a 4 km radius were evacuated by the RCMP.  On April 25, 2002 TransCanada completed the repairs and Line 100-3 was fully restored to normal service on July 5, 2002.

properties.name: Epidemic : Walkerton ON
properties.description: Walkerton ON, May 19 - July 14, 2000. E. coli O157:H7 and Campylobacter jejuni bacteria contaminated Walkerton's drinking water supply through Well 5, sickening more than 2,300 people and killing six.  The primary contamination source was manure spread on a farm near Well 5.  Contributing factors to this disaster, as identified by the Report on the Walkerton Inquiry, included failure to use continuous cholorine and turbidity monitors, improper operating practices at the Walkerton Public Utilities Commission, and the provincial government's budget reductions to the Ministry of Environment.

properties.name: Epidemic : Toronto ON
properties.description: Toronto ON, September 24, 2005.  In the fall of 2005, a long-term care facility in the City of Toronto named Seven Oaks experienced an outbreak of Legionnaires' disease. A total of 135 people were infected (70 residents, 39 staff, 21 visitors, and 5 people who lived or worked near the home). Twenty-three (23) residents died. For the first 10 days, the cause of the outbreak was unknown. On 16 October, the Minister of Health and Long-Term Care established an Expert Review Panel on the Legionnaires' Disease Outbreak to assess the progress Ontario has made since SARS, to identify the key lessons from the recent Legionnaires' disease outbreak, and provide advice on how to strengthen infectious disease control in Ontario.

properties.name: Epidemic : Across Canada, largely in the Greater Toronto area
properties.description: Across Canada, 13 March to August, 2003. Severe acute respiratory syndrome (SARS) emerged in November 2002 in Asia. It is described as a droplet-spread viral illness. The outbreak affected Toronto and the Greater Toronto Area the most. According to the Government of Ontario, there were 375 probable and suspected cases and 44 deaths.

properties.name: Epidemic : Across Canada
properties.description: Across Canada, August, 2008. Listeria monocytogenes spread by contaminated Maple Leaf food products produced at its Bartor Road plant. The outbreak occurred in August 2008. A segment of the population that is most vulnerable became exposed. 57 people became seriously ill and 22 people died.

properties.name: Epidemic : Across Canada
properties.description: Across Canada, April, 2009 to February, 2010. A new strain of pandemic influenza. The first cases were seen in Mexico and it spread quickly across the globe. In Canada, there were 8,582 hospitalizations, 1,448 cases admitted to ICU and 425 deaths.

properties.name: Epidemic : Glengarry Hospital, Victoria BC
properties.description: Glengarry Hospital, Victoria BC, April 6, 2010. A Norovirus outbreak at Chandler was declared on April 6 and affected a total of 39 residents. A respiratory outbreak was first declared on April 22 after an increase in the number of cases and several deaths occurred at the Chandler Unit. On April 29, two residents on the Fairfield Unit also became ill with respiratory symptoms. No new cases of respiratory illness have occurred on Fairfield since  April 29. A total of 21 residents at Glengarry Hospital (19 at Chandler Unit and 2 at Fairfield Unit) were affected by a respiratory illness. Of these 21 individuals, 10 have died (9 on Chandler, 1 on Fairfield). Three staff members also experienced respiratory symptoms.

properties.name: Earthquake : Val-des-Bois and Gracefield QC
properties.description: Val-des-Bois and Gracefield QC, June 23, 2010. At 1:41pm local time, a 5.0 earthquake occurred near Val-des-Bois Quebec.  The effects were felt as far away as Ottawa.  The depth was 18km.  A bridge on highway 307 near Bowman Quebec collapsed, causing significant delays, and a bridge on highway 105 in Gracefield Quebec was closed due to damage.  A state of emergency was called in Gracefield, but was lifted on the 26th.  Approximately 300 households near the epicentre lost power for about an hour.

properties.name: Residential : Toronto ON
properties.description: Toronto ON, July 20, 2008. Hundreds of residents of an east-Toronto apartment tower were evacuated after an explosion rocked their building. The blast, thought to have occured in an underground hydro vault, injured 10 people. Some nearby homes were also evacuated.

properties.name: Residential : Edmonton AB
properties.description: Edmonton AB, July 21, 2007. Hundreds of Edmonton redidents start trying to put their lives back together after a "wall of fire" swept through their neighbourhood, destroying 18 townhomes and damaging 76 more.

properties.name: Residential : Notre-Dame-du-Lac QC
properties.description: Notre-Dame-du-Lac QC, May 14, 2002. A fire destroyed l'Abattoir du Breton, located in a small community in eastern Quebec.  Of the 3200 residents, 1700 were evacuated due to their proximity to the abattoir (a 1.5 kilometre radius). A total of 2600 pigs died in the fire. The abattoir was the main employer in the region and 500 people lost their jobs. Emergency officials were concerned about the health hazards of ammonia, possibly in either the air or in the town's water system. Thirty residents were again evacuated when it was proven that ammonia was leaking from the abattoir.

properties.name: Residential : Calgary AB
properties.description: Calgary AB, May 5, 2002.  Fire gutted the Waterford Complex, a condominium development near downtown Calgary.

properties.name: Non-Residential : Kingsville ON
properties.description: Kingsville ON, June 21, 2002. Four million pounds of styrene incinerated.

properties.name: Non-Residential : Hamilton ON
properties.description: Hamilton ON, June 3, 2007. An industrial fire occurred at a computer facility in Hamilton, involving 5000 square feet of pallets loaded with computer parts, casings and some of the empty plastic barrels located outside the building.

properties.name: Non-Residential : Galiano Island BC
properties.description: Galiano Island BC, July 24, 2006. About 120 permanent residents and visitors were forced to leave their homes after a fire broke out at the southern end of the island. The fire was belive to have sparked in a gravel pit.

properties.name: Non-Residential : Windsor ON
properties.description: Windsor ON, May 25, 2007. Explosion and fire at an auto body shop; about 600 homes and businesses along with two schools were evacuated at the height of the blaze under the state of emergency, which lasted two hours.

properties.name: Flood : Selkirk MB
properties.description: Selkirk MB, April 3, 2007. Rising river water due to an ice jam has flooded low-lying areas of the city, forcing about 120 senior citizens from two waterfront condominium complexes.

properties.name: Flood : Red Earth First Nation SK
properties.description: Red Earth First Nation SK, April 19, 2007. The band council's decision to evacuate 691 residents from the northern reserve, mainly children, elderly residents and pregnant women, came as water covered one-third of a main access road, which divides the reserve.

properties.name: Flood : Saint-Joseph et VallÃ©e QC
properties.description: Saint-Joseph et VallÃ©e QC, October 28, 2006. In Saint-Joseph and VallÃ©e, approximately 50 homes and 30 businesses were affected by a flash flood.

properties.name: Flood : Aklavik NT
properties.description: Aklavik NT, May 27, 2006. Aklavik was evacuated for about a week in late May, and infrastructure damaged after the Peel River Channel overflowed its banks, swamping the low-lying town under several feet of water.

properties.name: Flood : Red Earth SK
properties.description: Red Earth SK, April, 13, 2006. In northeastern Saskatchewan, the Red River First Nation scrambled to avoid the threatening Carrot River as leaders ordered a general evacuation of the band of 1,100.

properties.name: Flood : Kashechewan ON
properties.description: Kashechewan ON, April 23, 2006. Spring flooding has forced hundreds of people to leave the northern Ontario reserve of Kashechewan. Kashechewan declared a state of emergency when water levels rose quickly and asked for immediate help from the province.

properties.name: Flood : Slocan River BC
properties.description: Slocan River BC, May 20, 2006. Dozens of homes were evacuated in the West Kootenay region of BC and hundreds more were on alert as rivers, fed by heavy rains and melting snowpacks, risked overflowing.

properties.name: Flood : Regional municipalities of Daly, Sifton, Blanshard, Brandon, Strathclair and Woodworth, Oak Lake, Rivers and Dominion City, Melita, Elphinstone, Rural Municipality of Franklin and the town of Deloraine and The Pas MB
properties.description: Melita, Oak Lake, Elphinstone, Rural Municipality of Franklin, Deloraine and The Pas MB, June 2, 2005.  Manitoba received between 100175 mm of rain resulting in summer flooding.   Regional municipalities of Daly, Sifton, Blanshard, Strathclair and Woodworth and the towns of Oak Lake and Rivers encountered major problems of seepage and basement flooding, damage to municipal roads and overland flooding of agricultural lands.  44 provincial highways and over 100 municipal roads were damaged.  Approximately, 380 homes and 19 families were forced to evacuate the area.  Thirteen municipalities declared a local state of emergency and more than 100 requested disaster financial assistance. It is expected that flood could cost more than $350 M including crop damage.

properties.name: Flood : Cumberland House, Cumberland House Cree First Nation SK
properties.description: Cumberland House, Cumberland House, Cree First Nation SK, June 23, 2005.  Approximately 2,000 residents of Cumberland House were evacuated to Prince Albert after the Saskatchewan River began flooding.  Saskatchewan Environment issued a boil water advisory for the residents. Movement of most ferries on the North and South Saskatchewan rivers was suspended.

properties.name: Flood : Quebec
properties.description: Quebec, August 31, 2005.  The aftermath of Hurricane Katrina was felt in Quebec where heavy rain hit the Basse-CÃ´te-Nord region. The region received 80 to 100 mm of rain. Over flown rivers and washed out culverts were seen in the towns of Vanier and Charlesbourg. These events led to flooding. August 31 was Montreal's P.E. Trudeau's wettest day that month as well as the wettest August day for Quebec City.

properties.name: Flood : Stephenville NL
properties.description: Stephenville NL, September 27, 2005.  The town of Stephenville received 110 mm of rain, causing flooding in the region.  More than 80 homes were flooded completely.  A state of emergency was declared and approximately 200 people were forced to leave their homes.

properties.name: Flood : Terrace, Smithers & Mount Currie BC
properties.description: Terrace, Smithers & Mount Currie BC, June 5, 2007. About 125 homes have been evacuated and about 1,100 others are on evacuation alert alongside the swollen Skeena and Bulkley rivers near Terrace and Smithers.

properties.name: Flood : Prince George BC
properties.description: Prince George BC, December 10, 2007. An ice jam in the Nechako River which, at one point, stretched as long as 33km, caused localized flooding. A state of emergency was declared

properties.name: Flood : Port Bruce ON
properties.description: Port Bruce ON, February 18, 2008. The small community, where Catfish Creek empties into Lake Erie east of Port Stanley, was flooded in places by knee-deep water that forced as many as 100 families to evacuate homes or prevented them from leaving.

properties.name: Flood : Belleville ON
properties.description: Belleville ON, April 14, 2008. A state of emergency was declared after water from the Moira River flooded dozens of homes and shut down roads.

properties.name: Flood : Paddockwood SK
properties.description: Paddockwood SK, April 14, 2008. The Rural Municipality of Paddockwood declared a state of emergency when flood waters rose more than one metre and started to cover main access roads.

properties.name: Flood : Trent Hills ON
properties.description: Trent Hills ON, April 17, 2008. Over a period of 24 hours, water levels in the tri-lakes increased 12 centimetres. The municipality of Trent Hills declared a state of emergency and continued sandbagging efforts.

properties.name: Flood : Albany River ON
properties.description: Albany River ON, April 25, 2008. More than a dozen aircraft were poised to help evacuate nearly 1,900 residents of Kashechewan and Fort Albany, reserves in the coastal area of James Bay, some 450kms north of Timmins.

properties.name: Flood : Quebec City QC
properties.description: Quebec City QC, April 29, 2008. A combination of swollen rivers and fears of mudslides caused Quebecers to be ordered out of their homes.

properties.name: Flood : Saint John River NB
properties.description: Saint John River NB, April 30, 2008. Flooding along the Saint John River caused as many as 1,000 people to evacuate their homes.

properties.name: Flood : James Bay ON
properties.description: James Bay ON, May 9, 2008. A serious flood risk is forcing about 1,200 people from their homes along the coast of James Bay.

properties.name: Flood : High River AB
properties.description: High River AB, May 24, 2008. Surging water levels on the Highwood River forced the town of High River to declare a state of local emergency.

properties.name: Flood : British Columbia
properties.description: British Columbia, May 2002.  High snow-pack levels, rapid melting and heavy rainfall caused severe runoff and flooding in areas of B.C. except Vancouver Island and the Central Coast. The spring freshet caused significant damage to private properties, public transportation corridors, and recreation facilities.

properties.name: Flood : Southern Manitoba
properties.description: Southern Manitoba, April 2001.  Southern Manitoba suffered significant losses during spring flooding.  Highway infrastructures, businesses and private and public properties were extensively damaged.

properties.name: Flood : Peace River area BC
properties.description: Peace River area BC, June 2001.  The region was subjected to many intense precipitation events.  Increased tributary levels combined with the spring freshet caused the over-saturation of the soil and surface runoff.  This in turn triggered several landslides that cut-off highways.  Property and infrastructure damage was extensive. Pink Mountain and Halfway River were both affected.

properties.name: Flood : Northeast and Central British Columbia
properties.description: Northeast and Central British Columbia, July 2001.  A severe five-day rainstorm caused flood damage to 100 homes and to critical infrastructure.  More than 200 mm of rain fell.  Roads and bridges were washed out, businesses and public and private properties were damaged, two trains derailed, and people were temporarily stranded.

properties.name: Flood : Vanguard SK
properties.description: Vanguard SK, July 3, 2000.  The Village of Vanguard and seven surrounding municipalities experienced a severe flood, causing extensive damage to private property and public infrastructure. More than 333 mm of rain â€“ equivalent to the area's annual rainfall â€“ fell on the area in less than 10 hours. Roads were closed, basements flooded, and two bridges were washed out. Nine families were forced from their homes due to flooding.  As well, residents were advised not to drink the water for two weeks because the village's water treatment plant and sewer system were submerged during the flood. No deaths or injuries were reported.

properties.name: Flood : Southern Manitoba
properties.description: Southern Manitoba, July 7-14, 2000.   Heavy rains occurred throughout July, causing major problems in some areas.  During one storm, on July 7 2000, roads were washed out and crops flattened as between 80 millimetres and 100 millimetres of rain in four hours. High winds reached almost 125 kilometres an hour in some areas and lightning strikes reached 1,000 hits an hour in some spots.  Backed-up sewers, flooded basements and blocked drainage systems were reported.  Heavy rains have saturated the soil, resulting in overland flooding in various areas across the province.

properties.name: Flood : Sydney NS
properties.description: Sydney NS, November 2-11, 2000.  Heavy rains hit Cape Breton and Victoria County for nearly ten days, causing flooding and damages to homes and businesses.  Almost 100 millimetres of rain fell in a 24-hour period, flooding streets and forcing the evacuation of 200 families.  One woman was trapped in her car and suffered injuries when a massive culvert collapsed due water pressure.  A boil order was in effect for a week for 1,000 residents in Donkin and at least 2 weeks for the 30,000 residents of Glace Bay, Reserve Mines and Dominion.

properties.name: Flood : Winnipeg MB
properties.description: Winnipeg MB, May 29, 2010. Heavy rains over the course of a week caused significant flooding in Winnipeg and the surrounding area.  619 of the 180,000 residential properties in Winnipeg reported being flooded.  As a result, 420 were damaged by overland flooding, while 199 suffered sewage backups.  The province offered disaster financial assistance for this event alongside other events which occurred over the spring and summer.  Heavy rains over the course of a week caused significant flooding in Winnipeg and the surrounding area.

properties.name: Flood : Southern Alberta and Saskatchewan
properties.description: Southern Alberta and Saskatchewan, June 17, 2010. Record rainfall resulted in extensive flooding in Alberta and Saskatchewan, washing out a portion of the Trans-Canada highway and shutting down part of the Canadian Pacific rail line.  40 people on the Blood Tribe reserve, 75 homes in Maple Creek, and 600 households in Medicine Hat were forced to evacuate.  Disaster financial assistance was provided by both provinces.

properties.name: Flood : Attawapiskat First Nation ON
properties.description: Attawapiskat FN, ON, May 2002. Approximately 1200 people were evacuated to Moosonee and Timmins following the flooding of the Attawapiskat River. A municipal state of emergency was declared.

properties.name: Flood : Municipalities of Ignace, Fort Frances, Rainy River, Alberton, Atikokan, Chapple, Dawson, Emo, La Valle, Lake of the Woods, Morley, Machin; Township of Sioux-Narrows - Nestor Falls, ON
properties.description: Municipalities of Ignace, Fort Frances, Rainy River, Alberton, Atikokan, Chapple, Dawson, Emo, La Valle, Lake of the Woods, Morley, Machin; Township of Sioux-Narrows - Nestor Falls ON, June 9-11, 2002.  Parts of northwestern Ontario were declared disaster areas because of severe flooding. Roads and highways were washed out and closed, power and telecommunication lines were disrupted, and private properties were greatly damaged.

properties.name: Flood : Southern Alberta
properties.description: Southern AB, June 11, 2002.  Approximately 280 mm of rain fell on the area within a few days.  The heavy rain and the unusually late spring runoff caused mudslides and forced sewage into river systems, and power lines were damaged in Waterton Lake National Park.  A local state of emergency was declared for the areas of: Pincher Creek, County of Warner, Village of Sterling, Village of Warner, Village of Foremost, and the Town of Coaldale.  Two hundred residents from the Blood First Nation and 150 residents from the Peigan First Nation were evacuated.

properties.name: Flood : Southeast MB
properties.description: Southeast MB, June 11, 2002. Ten communities declared a state of emergency following severe flooding of homes and roads. About 240 mm of rain fell, causing the worst flooding southeast Manitoba had seen in 45 years. Levels of the Roseau River declined for a few days; however, additional flooding was expected the following week given the record water levels in the American portion of the river and the expected crest in southeast Manitoba. Residents and flood workers built dikes and laid sandbags as a preventative measure in the event of further flooding. Several roads were closed and some of these washed out or were covered with water. Crops were severely damaged because fields were submerged under water, and homes were inundated.

properties.name: Flood : Badger NL
properties.description: The entire town of Badger, NL was evacuated when the three rivers Badger-Exploits, Red Indian and Badger overflowed their banks due to ice jamming. The town's water supply was contaminated after the sewer system failed.  Power supply was cut off to all flooded homes.  Approximately 200 homes were affected by the flooding.  The Canadian Red Cross, local officials, the RCMP and the Emergency Measures Organization were cooperating to find shelter for approximately 80 families.

properties.name: Flood : Oxford and Truro NS
properties.description: Oxford and Truro NS, March 31, 2003. Heavy rains and snowmelt caused flooding in communities on the Atlantic coast. States of emergency were declared in the towns of Oxford and Truro NS where 150 and 120 people respectively were evacuated from their homes. Two people died as there car was swept off the road by flood waters in Pinehurst. Nova Scotia's Transportation Department has reported that the flooding has destroyed or damaged 47 bridges and has affected 200 roads. See Prince Edward Island and Newfoundland entries for more information on this event.

properties.name: Flood : West Coast of Newfoundland
properties.description: West Coast of Newfoundland, March 31, 2003. Western Newfoundland experienced flooding as a result of both heavy rain and mild temperatures. Some of the communities affected include: Codroy Valley, Cox's Cove, and Corner Brook. These communities faced washed out roads as well as damaged water and sewage systems. A landslide on the Trans-Canada Highway restricted access between Gallants and George's Lake. See Nova Scotia and Prince Edward Island entries for more information on this event.

properties.name: Flood : The Bois-Francs, ChaudiÃ¨re-Appalaches, Beauce, l'Outaouais, LanaudiÃ¨re, and Abitibi-TÃ©miscamingue regions QC
properties.description: The Bois-Francs, ChaudiÃ¨re-Appalaches, Beauce, l'Outaouais, LanaudiÃ¨re, and Abitibi-TÃ©miscamingue regions QC, August 4, 2003

properties.name: Flood : Vancouver Island and South-western British Columbia
properties.description: Vancouver Island and South-western British Columbia, October 16-23, 2003. Heavy rains resulted in major flooding, particularly to Squamish and Pemberton where states of emergency were declared. Flooding in the Squamish Valley, Cheakamus Valley, and Paradise Valley resulted in the evacuation of 700 people from those areas. Another 50 people were evacuated from the Vancouver Island region. Two vehicles were swept into Rutherford Creek (north of Whistler). One passenger survived, while two died.

properties.name: Flood : South-Central Manitoba
properties.description: South-Central Manitoba, March 24-26, 2004. A combination of spring runoff and heavy rainfall brought flooding to Manitoba's South-Central region. Some affected communities include: Pembina, Morris, Winnipeg, Selkirk and Lac du Bonnet. States of emergency were declared in the Rural Municipalities of Franklin, Tache and St. Clements. Twenty-one people were evacuated from the Dakota Plains and Peguis First Nations. More than 1,000 were evacuated when the Red River overflowed.

properties.name: Flood : Attawapiskat ON
properties.description: Attawapiskat ON, May 19, 2004.  Due to ice-jam flooding in the Attawapiskat River, approximately 1,700 people from the  James Bay Cree First Nation community of Attawapiskat were evacuated by air to Moosonee, Cochrane and Timmins.

properties.name: Flood : The Pas MB
properties.description: The Pas MB, July 21, 2004.  Heavy rains on already saturated ground led to an overloading of  the town's joint sewage and storm drain system flooding homes in The Pas.  Approximately 400 homes in the town were damaged.  Dozens of people were reported sick  with intestinal and bronchial illnesses after attempting to clean-up after the flood.   The costs of the damages could reach as high as $5 million.

properties.name: Flood : Kashechewan ON
properties.description: Kashechewan First Nation, ON. April 23, 2005.  Nearly 200 people were flown out of a remote reserve in northern Ontario to Moosonee after flooding filled 39 basements with raw sewage.  Spring flooding on the Albany River caused the sewage system to back up and contaminated the community water system.

properties.name: Flood : Fredericton, Jemseg, Sheffield, Maugerville NB
properties.description: Fredericton, Jemseg, Sheffield and Maugerville NB, May 1, 2005.  Several days of rain caused flood in the communities of Jemseg, Sheffield and Maugerville in New Brunswick and forced approximately 40 families to evacuate their riverside homes.  Several families were remained stranded in their homes, as all roads were covered by water and only way to get around was by canoe.  Due to high water level Highway between Fredericton and Saint John remained blocked for many days.  The flood caused thousand of dollars of damage.

properties.name: Flood : Fort Good Hope NT
properties.description: Fort Good Hope NT, May 11-14, 2005. Jackfish Creek and Rabbitskin River rose to the point that 10 families and 8 seniors had to leave their Fort Good Hope homes. A state of emergency was declared.

properties.name: Flood : Bridgewater NS
properties.description: Bridgewater NS, May 26, 2005.  As of May 27, 383 mm of rain had fallen in the region (Nova Scotia's Fancy Lake watershed) causing overland flooding in number of communities.  A local state of emergency was declared and approximately 100 people were evacuated.

properties.name: Flood : Prince Edward Island
properties.description: Prince Edward Island, March 31, 2003.  The province was subjected to a severe rainstorm causing flooding and resulting in damage to both private and public property.

properties.name: Flood : Baie Verte Peninsula NL
properties.description: Baie Verte Peninsula NL, April 17, 2007.  A severe rainstorm caused flooding along Newfoundland and Labrador's Northeast coast.  A number of communities in the Baie Verte Peninsula region of the province, such as Burlington and Middle Arm, were affected.

properties.name: Flood : Pangnirtung NU
properties.description: Pangnirtung NU, June 8 and 9, 2008.  A flood affected Pangnirtung, damaging two bridges and cutting residents off from essential services.

properties.name: Flood : Hay River NT
properties.description: Hay River NT, May 5 and 6, 2008. Overland flooding due to snow melt and the spring backup of Hay River resulted in damages to public and private property.

properties.name: Flood : Rock Creek and Henderson Corner in the Klondike Valley YT
properties.description: Rock Creek and Henderson Corner in the Klondike Valley YT, May 01, 2009.  Overland flooding from May 1 to May 3 affected the unincorporated areas of Rock Creek and Henderson Corner in the Klondike Valley, resulting in the evacuation of 28 people and damage to both private property and public infrastructure, such as roads and recreational facilities.

properties.name: Flood : Notre-Dame-des-Prairies
properties.description: During the week from June 28 to July 4, a quasi-stationary low-pressure system stalled over eastern Ontario and Quebec. Excessive rains of 140 mm damaged roads and bridges, and flooded basements.  The hardest hit areas were in Charlevoix, Mauricie and Parent. Flood waters filled 50 houses in Notre-Dame-des-Prairies on July 1, and collapsed a street in Entrelacs when a stream overflowed. The flow rate on several rivers exceeded historic records.

properties.name: Flood : Meat Cove NS
properties.description: Meat Cove NS, August 22, 2010.  A flash flood struck the small community of Meat Cove early in the morning.  The five local bridges suffered major damage, two being swept up by the sea.  As a result, the 35 residences were isolated, along with 25 tourists.  Environment Canada reported 69.8mm of rain in the area.  Officials from the Emergency Management Office worked with the RCMP, Emergency Health Services, the Canadian Red Cross, and others to provide emergency services to the community.  Access to the area was restricted to boats until August 30 when a temporary bridge over Salmon River was completed.

properties.name: Flood : Saint John, Miramichi and Restigouche rivers NB
properties.description: Saint John, Miramichi and Restigouche rivers NB, April 5 to May 4, 2009. A freshet in spring 2009 caused flooding in a number of communities, primarily from the formation of ice jams which raised water levels along the Saint John, Miramichi, and Restigouche rivers from April 5 to May 4.  The flooding caused damages to private homes and businesses and to public sector infrastructure such as roadways.  Preliminary eligible costs are estimated at $2.0 million, which would result in a federal share of approximately $626,000.

properties.name: Flood : GaspÃ© and Bonaventure QC
properties.description: GaspÃ© and Bonaventure QC, December 2010. Heavy rains moved through QuÃ©bec causing flooding from December 5 to 7 and 13 to 15.  A total of 57 municipalities were declared eligible for disaster financial assistance with the provincial government.  Approximately 125 residents were evacuated during the flooding on the 15th, with between 300 and 500 homes in the GaspÃ© region being flooded.

properties.name: Flood : High River, City of Calgary, City of Red Deer, Red Deer County, Drumheller, Black Diamond, Pincher Creek, Fort Macleod, Okotoks, Turner Valley, Sundre, Mountainview County, District of Foothills, Clearwater County, Siksika First Nation, Tsuu T'ina First Nation AB
properties.description: High River, City of Calgary, City of Red Deer, Red Deer County, Drumheller, Black Diamond, Pincher Creek, Fort Macleod, Okotoks, Turner Valley, Sundre, Mountainview County, District of Foothills, Clearwater County, Siksika First Nation, Tsuu T'ina First Nation AB, June 8, 2005. Heavy rainfall and high water across the southern Alberta caused massive flooding as many regional rivers flooded.  A state of emergency was declared in municipalities across the region. Severe flooding caused evacuation in these communities Calgary (2000), Sundre (1300), Drumheller (3200), High River (200), Foothills (70), Okotoks (58), Red Deer County (200).  Officials called the floods a â€œonce-in-200-year eventâ€.  Approximately 40,000 homes suffered flood damage as a result of record rains in June.

properties.name: Flood : New Brunswick and Nova Scotia
properties.description: New Brunswick and Nova Scotia, December 13, 2010.  New Brunswick and Nova Scotia experienced heavy rainfall resulting in extensive flooding causing damages to housing, roads, and loss of power to approximately 80,000 residents in Nova Scotia.  At least 44 residents from St. George and Nashwaak Valley were displaced from their homes.  Both provinces provided provincial aid to victims.

properties.name: Flood : Saint-Jean-sur-Richelieu (Richelieu River) QC
properties.description: Saint-Jean-sur-Richelieu (Richelieu River) QC, April 22 to June 15, 2011. Extensive flooding in the Saint-Jean-sur-Richelieu (Richelieu River) began on April 22, 2011 and peaked on May 23, 2011.  During the event peak, 1,619 homes had been evacuated and 2,663 homes were flooded. As of June 14, 2011, there were still 795 residences flooded and 1,263 remained evacuated. Those who could return home began clean up efforts as early as June 10, 2011.

properties.name: Flood : Assiniboine, Roseau and Red Rivers MB
properties.description: Assiniboine, Roseau, and Red Rivers MB, April 28 to June 17, 2011. By April 28, 2011 flooding resulted in fifteen communities declaring states of emergency while 1,772 individuals had been evacuated province wide.  1,547 of these evacuees were from First Nationscommunities.  INAC worked collaboratively with First Nations communities to develop flood action plans with pre-emptive activities.  As of June 15, 2011, 2,543 individuals had been evacuated and thirty-two communities had declared states of emergency. Current cost estimates from the Province  is approximately $100 M and, if all expenditures are eligible, this may translate into an estimated federal share of $87.5 M (estimated).

properties.name: Flood : Eckville, Lacombe, Paddle River, Fort Vermilion, and Peace River AB
properties.description: Eckville, Paddle River, Fort Vermilion, and Peace River AB, July 12, 2011 to July 14, 2011. According to the AB River Forecast Centre, water levels on the Peace River exceed 1 in 100 year event levels near Fort Vermilion. The region was divided into three segments to facilitate emergency response. All of 'Area A' included all of the low-lying areas, and was placed under immediate evacuation order. On July 12, there were approximately 100 flooded homes in Eckville. 700 homes were without electricity or phone services. Roads and highways were significantly damaged.

properties.name: Flood : Dauphin Lake, Souris River, Assiniboine River, Pipestone Creek, Oak Lake, Plum Lakes, Plum Creek, and the Qu'Appelle River MB
properties.description: Dauphin Lake, Souris River, Assiniboine River, Pipestone Creek, Oak Lake, Plum Lakes, Plum Creek, and the Qu'Appelle River MB, June 2 to July 9, 2011. On June 3, 2011, 1,961 individuals were evacuated from the Ochre River, Alonsa, and Sioux Valley First Nations, and 37 communities declared states of emergency due to extensive flooding.  Another 45 residences were given mandatory evacuation orders in the Dauphin Lake, Ochre River/Cresent Beach area on June 4. On June 6, the Sastachewan Watershed Authority released a large amount of water from the Tobin Lake Dam, which flows towards the flood zone.  By June 6, 40 communities were under a State of Local Emergency with a total of 2,058 evacuees registered through the Canadian Red Cross and MANFF. Effective June 28, there were a total of 2,937 evacuees, 42 local declared States of Emergency with 13 of these being First Nations communities. On July 9, 2011, evacuation orders were lifted for Portage La Prairie, Souris, Wawanesa, and Glenwood.

properties.name: Flood : Wollaston Lake SK
properties.description: Wollaston Lake SK, June 2 to 9, 2011. On June 1, 2011, the Saskatchewan Emergency Organization reported that a 500 hectare fire was burning approximately 1.5 kms southwest of the community of Wollaston Lake. Winds blowing in from the southwest caused the fire and smoke to encroach upon the community, and the fire increased to 1,100 hectares by the following day. On June 2, a total of 1,137 residents were evacuated but damages to structures had not been reported at that time.

properties.name: Flood : Brandon MB
properties.description: Brandon MB, May 10 to 28, 2011. 14 homes were evacuated in Brandon, MB on May 10 due to extensive flooding. By May 15, a total of 3,623 individuals had been evacuated from the following communities: Archie, Arthur, Brandon, Cameron, Cornwallis, Dauphin, Ellice, Elton, Emerson, Langfor, Lake St. Martin First Nations, Ritchot, St. Clements, St. Lazare Village, Sandy Bay First Nations, Sioux Valley First Nations, South Norfolk, Stanley, and Whitewater. 120 provincial roads and 655 municipal roads were closed as a result of the flooding.

properties.name: Flood : Weyburn and Estavan SK
properties.description: Weyburn and Estavan SK, June 17 to 21, 2011. An Emergency Operations Centre and local State of Emergency were put into effect on June 17, 2011 as a result of extensive flooding in the City of Weyburn and City of Estavan, SK. Approximately 200 homes were known to be affected in Weyburn, and 383 residents were evacuated from a mobile trailer park in Estavan, June 17. On June 18, officials reported that the capacity of the treatment plant had exceeded its capacity, and Environment Canada granted permission to pump sewage directly into the Souris River. Repairs were conducted at the treatment plant to address the capacity issue.  SaskPower reported scattered and localized power outages throughout the region. Residients in most areas were given the all clear to return to their homes on June 28, 2011.

properties.name: Flood : Calgary AB
properties.description: Tsuu Tâ€™ina First Nation evacuated 40 families (approximately 120 individuals) from Calgary AB due to flooding and road washouts.  The Stone Tribe evacuated an additional seven families (approximately 21 individuals) due to flooding.  Also, the Siksika First Nation and Town of High River have issued voluntary evacuation orders for Hidden Valley and High River areas.

properties.name: Flood : Yarmouth and Halifax NS
properties.description: Yarmouth and Halifax NS, November 7 to December 15, 2010. High winds and heavy rains over a one month period resulted in the "worst flooding in a century."  On November 7, 2010, storms began with 215 mm of rain falling in Yarmouth, NS and 172 mm in Halifax. On November 9, 120 families were evacuated from Yarmouth, and several more families were evacuated from nearby Lequille (Annapolis Royal) and Lake Vaughn. A state of emergency was declared when more than 100 mm of rain fell within 18 hours flooding and overwhelming local resources. Rains continued at a high precipitation rate through to December 15, 2010. During this time, roads and bridges were washed out, homes were badly damaged by flood waters, and power was lost to more than 46,000 homes. On May 19, 2011, the Emergency Management Office of Nova Scotia released a statement indicating the Disaster Financial Assistance Programâ€™s approval for cost-sharing between the province and Ottawa.

properties.name: Flood : Medicine Hat AB
properties.description: Medicine Hat AB, June 18 to 21, 2010. Days of heavy rains in the small creeks surrounding Medicine Hat, AB resulted in flash flooding events. On June 18, the town of Irvine (35 km from Medicine Hat) was partially submerged in water that was up to 15 feet deep. 20 homes were evacuated from Irvine. As waters travelled towards Medicine Hat, sensors measured a 12.5 foot increase in mean depth over less than three hours. 220 residents were evacuated from Medicine Hat. Extensive damage to infrastructure including bridges, roads, the Trans-Canada Highway, and utilities resulted from the flooding event.

properties.name: Flood : Kingcome Inlet and Bella Coola BC
properties.description: Kingcome Inlet and Bella Coola BC, September 24-25, 2010. Flooding caused by heavy rainfall resulted in flooding that destroyed the highway leading into Bella Coola BC. Residents of Kingcome Inlet were evacuated by helicopter when water continued to rise. Approximately 100 persons were evacuated from Bella Coola and another 75 persons from Kingcome Inlet.

properties.name: Flood : Duncan and North Cowichan (Vancouver Island) BC
properties.description: Duncan and North Cowichan (Vancouver Island) BC, November 14-19, 2009. Flooding caused by heavy rains and high tides resulted in the destruction of 50 homes and the evacuation of 300 homes (approximately 900 residents).  The storm also caused power outages affecting thousands of homes on Vancouver Island, in the Fraser Valley and within the BC interior.

properties.name: Flood : Roseau River First Nation, Sioux Falls, Peguis First Nation, St. Andrews, St. Clements and Selkirk MB
properties.description: Roseau River First Nation, Sioux Falls, Peguis First Nation, St. Andrews, St. Clements and Selkirk MB, March 24, 2009. Overland flooding from March 24 to May 21 caused by a combination of snowmelt, seasonal precipitation and the spring breakup affected southern Manitoba's watershed areas of the Red, Pembina, Assiniboine, and Souris Rivers.  The event caused flooding of houses and evacuations from communities including Roseau River First Nation, Sioux Falls, Peguis First Nation, St. Andrews, St. Clements and Selkirk.  The flooding also resulted in damage to public infrastructure such as bridges, roads, and highways. Three principal factors led to the spring flooding: 1) Heavy autumn rains, about 43 per cent more than normal, saturated the ground just before freezing in early December, which left little room for absorbing snow melt in the spring; 2) It was a snowy winter in southern Manitoba with some 25 per cent more snowfall than normal. Heavy snowfalls and copious spring rains swelled the critical headwaters of North Dakota sending excessive waters north into Canada via the Red River and its tributaries; and, 3) An unseasonably cold spring slowed basin snow melting, ice decaying in rivers, and overland flow from ditches and culverts.

properties.name: Heat Event : Vancouver and Fraser BC
properties.description: Vancouver and Fraser BC, July 27 to August 3, 2009. During an eight day period from July 27, 2009 to August 3, 2009, temperatures as high as 34.4 degrees centigrade were measured at Vancouver International Airport. During the same eight day period, the Fraser and Vancouver Coastal Health Authorities registered 455 deaths (from all causes and ages), as compared to an average of 321 during the equivalent calendar period for the preceeding years between 2004-2008 (Kosatsky, 2010).

properties.name: Hurricane / Typhoon / Tropical Storm : Newfoundland and Labrador
properties.description: Newfoundland and Labrador, September 21, 2010.  Hurricane Igor impacted Newfoundland and Labrador, causing extensive damages.  At the height of the hurricane, wind speeds in some areas were in excess of 170 km/h with rainfall reaching nearly 240 millimetres in parts of the province.  Approximately 90 communities were isolated due to washouts and road closures, and 22 communities had declared states of emergency.  Over 30,000 calls were made to the Emergency Operations Centre and over 100 families were displaced.  An 80-year-old man died when he was swept into the ocean during the storm.  1,000 troops were deployed by the Canadian Forces to assist in the wake of the disaster.  Canada Revenue Agency also provided tax relief measures to taxpayers affected by Hurricane Igor in Newfoundland and Labrador.

properties.name: Hurricane / Typhoon / Tropical Storm : Maritimes provinces
properties.description: Maritimes provinces, September 29, 2008. Emergency and power crews in parts of Atlantic Canada were at work trying to restore electricity as Hurricane Kyle, a Category 1 storm, swirled into the Maritimes, its high winds toppled power lines.

properties.name: Hurricane / Typhoon / Tropical Storm : Halifax NS
properties.description: Halifax NS, August 23, 2009.  Hurricane Bill dumped between 60 and 70 mm of rain with overland wind gusts of 87 km/h. A marine buoy off Nova Scotia recorded winds of 130 km/h and another buoy about 200 km southeast of Yarmouth recorded a maximum wave height of 26.4 metres. Bill's steady downpour and fierce winds knocked out power to 40,000 residents. More than a dozen flights from Halifax International Airport were cancelled and ferry services were suspended between Nova Scotia and Newfoundland. In Newfoundland and Labrador there were road washouts and some localized flooding.

properties.name: Hurricane / Typhoon / Tropical Storm : Newfoundland
properties.description: Newfoundland, August 2, 2007. Post-tropical storm Chantal dumped up to 150mm of rain in places on the eastern third of the island, flooding towns and washing out dozens of roads before moving out to sea.

properties.name: Hurricane / Typhoon / Tropical Storm : New Brunswick and Nova Scotia
properties.description: New Brunswick and Nova Scotia, November 4, 2007. Wind gusts of up to 135km/h from post-tropical storm Noel lashed the Maritimes, knocking out power to an estimated 190,000 homes and businesses across the region, while pounding surf and heavy rains washed out roads in some coastal areas.

properties.name: Hurricane / Typhoon / Tropical Storm : Saint John NB
properties.description: Saint John NB, September 7, 2008. Tropical storm Hanna soaked already water-logged East Coast communities, filling basements with over a metre of water and creating waist-deep flooding in downtown streets.

properties.name: Hurricane / Typhoon / Tropical Storm : Quebec, Newfoundland and Labrador, New Brunswick, Nova Scotia and Prince Edward Island
properties.description: Quebec, Newfoundland and Labrador, New Brunswick, Nova Scotia and Prince Edward Island, August 28-30, 2011. Tropical Storm Irene hit Canada approximately 100 km north-northeast of Sept-Iles QC, reaching the Labrador coast in the early morning hours of August 30, and continuing through to Nova Scotia and Prince Edward Island.  On August 28, Hydro-Quebec reported 300,000 households were without electricity.  By August 29, this was lowered to 130,000 hourseholds without electricity. One man was died while attempting to reach his family in the storm another went missing when his car was washed down river, and is presumed dead.  Approximately 300 residents were evacuated in Quebec. Wave heights of up to 5 metres were in effect in the Gulf of the St. Lawrence. Some parts of Labrador received up to 40 mm of rain overnight while Doaktown NB and Fredricton NB received 89 mm and 53 mm, respectively.  51,000 lost electricity in Nova Scotia, 150,000 in New Brunswick and approximately 18,000 in Prince Edward Island.

properties.name: Hurricane / Typhoon / Tropical Storm : Liverpool NS
properties.description: Liverpool NS, September 4, 2010. Hurricane Earl landed 35 km southwest of Liverpool, NS with wind speed of 110 km/hr and peak waves at 23 m in height.  200,000 homes were left without power, there were extensive damages to Halifax harbour, and trees uprooted throughout Newfoundland and Nova Scotia.

properties.name: Hurricane / Typhoon / Tropical Storm : Yarmouth County NS
properties.description: Yarmouth NS, September 28, 2008. Tropical Storm Kyle made landfall bringing heavy rains and powerful winds as high as 100 km/hr.  The high winds resulted in 40,000 being without power along with significant damage to infrastructure and personal property.

properties.name: Hurricane / Typhoon / Tropical Storm : Edmundston NB
properties.description: Edmundston NB, August 13-14, 2004. Tropical Depression Bonnie (result of Hurricane Bonnie) hit New Brunswick on August 13 bringing heavy rains and flooding to north-western New Brunswick. Edmundston received as much as 90 mm of rain. A car accident occurred as a result of the storm leading to one event-related fatality.

properties.name: Hurricane / Typhoon / Tropical Storm : Halifax NS and Charlottetown PE
properties.description: Halifax, NS and Charlottetown, PE, September 29, 2003. At 12:10 a.m. ADT, Hurricane "Juan" made landfall in Nova Scotia as one of most powerful and damaging hurricanes to ever affect Canada.  A 1.63 m storm surge occurred while Hurricane Juan made landfall just south of Halifax as a weak Class 2 hurricane. Water levels reached 2.9 m above chart datum, the highest water level recorded to date at this location. Winds gusted to 230 km/h in Halifax and waves outside Halifax Harbour reached a maximum height of 19 m. Extensive damage to buildings, docks, boardwalks, trails occurred in the Halifax region (especially the downtown waterfront).

properties.name: Hurricane / Typhoon / Tropical Storm : Southern coast of Newfoundland
properties.description: Southern coast of Newfoundland, September 19, 2001. Tropical Storm "Gabrielle". High tides, strong winds and record-breaking precipitation hit the southern coast of Newfoundland, particularly the Avalon Peninsula. Provincial, municipal, and private properties were greatly affected. Basements, streets, parks, schools and shopping malls were flooded. Power outages affected most of the province. Conflict arose between St-John's residents and the municipality over the inadequate sewer system; the sewer system could not manage the runoff.

properties.name: Energy : Ontario, Midwest and Northeast USA
properties.description: Ontario, Midwest and Northeast USA, August 14, 2003. Approximately 50 million (over 9 million in Ontario) people were affected by a blackout, some experiencing power outages for over 48 hours. A combination of employee, equipment, and monitoring failures ultimately led to the blackout. The initial triggering power outage was prompted by contact between sagging transmission lines and untrimmed trees in Ohio.

properties.name: Infestation : Kashechewan ON
properties.description: Keshechewan ON, October 27, 2005.  The Ontario government declared a state of emergency at a Keshechewan remote native reserve after discovering E.coli bacteria in the community's drinking water supply.  The tainted drinking water forced the evacuation of the reserve, home of approximately 1,100.  74 people, mostly families with children suffering from skin rashes and chronic diarrhea, were immediately flown to Sudbury and hospitalized for medical treatment.  Other remaining evacuees from the reserve were sent to other cities.

properties.name: Water : Montreal QC
properties.description: Montreal QC, August 12, 2002.  Montreal's worst ever water main break affected several sections of the city.  The city's waterworks system that stretches 2700 km in total has some sections that are over 100 years old.  Approximately 10 million gallons of water were lost before the water was turned off. In the St. Michel area, 1300 homes were affected by flooding and interruption in hydro services. Twenty-two thousand homes in the RiviÃ¨re des Prairies and Montreal East areas did not have water, and 40 homes were deemed uninhabitable due to severe water damage.

properties.name: Landslide : Passmore BC
properties.description: Passmore BC, April 13-14, 2000.  Two mudslides slid 320 metres down a mountainside, totalling about 150,000 cubic metres of dirt, rock and trees.  The slides buried the highway just south of Passmore in the Slocan Valley.  The mudslide toppled power lines, leaving about 4,000 residents without electricity and long distance phone service.  No one was injured in either slide.

properties.name: Landslide : North Vancouver BC
properties.description: North Vancouver BC, January 19, 2005.  A landslide killed one woman and triggered an emergency evacuation of about 100 homes.

properties.name: Landslide : North Vancouver BC
properties.description: North Vancouver BC, January 19, 2005.  A landslide of mud, debris and snow caused by more than 320 mm of rain completely destroyed two homes in North Vancouver.  One person died and nearly 100 homes were evacuated.  A state of emergency was declared in North Vancouver.

properties.name: Landslide : Daniels Harbour NL
properties.description: Daniels Harbour NL, April 15, 2007.

properties.name: Landslide : Khyex River BC
properties.description: Khyex River BC, November 28, 2003. The Khyex River Landslide occurred on November 28, 2003 between 00:20 and 00:30 PST. This is when Pacific Northern Gas Ltd noticed a pressure loss in the pipeline. Approximately 300 m of 8-inch pipeline was lost. As a result, most of Prince Rupert residents were without natural gas or heat for 10 days. A few days after the landslide occurred, a temporary 2-inch gas line was installed to restore partial service. This is a spectacular landslide because it not only flowed downstream, but crossed the river and flowed upstream for hundreds of metres. This type of landslide took place in very sensitive glaciomarine muds, and is called a retrogressive earthflow. The estimated volume of material displaced by the landslide is up to 4.7 million cubic metres. It is thought that the slope failure was triggered by erosion of the riverbank.

properties.name: Rail : Brantford ON
properties.description: Brantford ON, November 16, 2002.  Eight train cars were derailed as a result of a collision with a van. The derailed cars rolled down an embankment that adjoined a neighbourhood, causing 120 people from the immediate area to be evacuated for two days. There were no leaks reported, but the cars contained a residue of butylene and butane.

properties.name: Rail : Tyendinaga Township First Nation ON
properties.description: Tyendenaga Township First Nation ON, February 21, 2003. Two Canadian Pacific freight trains carrying hazardous materials collided, derailed and exploded in Tyendenaga Township First Nation near Melrose, Ontario.  Two crewmembers were injured and approximately 300 people were forced to leave their homes.  The township declared a state of emergency and ordered evacuation within a 2 km area of the site.

properties.name: Storm - Unspecified / Other : South-Central area of Manitoba (Cartier, Grey, Macdonald, Dufferin, Morris, Montcalm)
properties.description: South-Central Manitoba (Cartier, Grey, Macdonald, Dufferin, Morris, Montcalm), May 16 to 17, 2008.  Over the weekend, Manitoba experienced a wind storm producing damaging winds that caused extensive impacts to the public sector drainage system across a wide area of central Manitoba.

properties.name: Storm - Unspecified / Other : Montreal, Alma, La Tuque and Baie-Saint-Paul QC
properties.description: Montreal, Alma, La Tuque and Baie-Saint-Paul QC, May 14, 2011. Winds gusting up to 100 km/h wreaked havoc across Quebec on May 14. An 18-wheeler was one of six tractor-trailers pushed over on its side near Beloeil. Strong winds cut electricity to 70,000 people by downing hydro lines.  Winds also inflicted significant property damage: in Ste-Julie, winds uprooted hundreds of trees and tossed a gazebo and trampoline left dangling from power lines; in Alma, fallen trees crossed power lines, igniting a brush fire; in the La Tuque region, winds blew shingles off a hotel roof and dropped a street light on a home; and in Baie-Saint-Paul, winds snapped hydro poles into two and tore away roofs.

properties.name: Storm Surge : Maritime provinces
properties.description: Maritime provinces, January 21, 2000. A 1.36 m surge occurred as an intense storm passed 55 km east of Charlottetown bringing 70 km/h sustained winds to the region. The peak surge coincided with high tide resulting in a water level of 4.23 m above chart datum, the highest water level recorded to date at this location. Significant flooding occurred inundating more than 460 properties including gas stations and a power generating plant and damaging wharves.

properties.name: Storm Surge : Baie-Verte and Port Elgin NB
properties.description: Baie-Verte NB, January 2-3, 2010.  While there are no gauges in the Baie-Verte/Port Elgin area, Environment Canada reported that based on the gauge at Pointe du Chene the peak water level there lasted for approximately 2 hours.  Environment Canada indicated that water levels in the Baie-Verte/Port Elgin area would have been greater than the five feet recorded at Pointe du Chene due to the peak winds occurring there later in the storm.

properties.name: Storm Surge : Kings County PE
properties.description: Kings County PE, December 27, 2004. Panmure Island and Basin Head were particularly affected. In North Rustico, a man was rescued by firefighters from his flooded residence.

properties.name: Storm Surge : Eastern and Northern Coastline of New Brunswick
properties.description: Eastern and Northern Coastline of New Brunswick, October 29, 2000.  Extensive damage occurred during a severe storm surge with winds in excess of 130 km/h.  Private property, businesses and public infrastructure were damaged along the eastern and northern coast of New Brunswick.  The emerging shellfish aquaculture industry (which includes mussels, oysters and clams) was also greatly affected.

properties.name: Storm Surge : Delta BC
properties.description: Delta BC, February 4, 2006. A strong winter storm with sustained winds of 75 km/h brought an approximately 1 m storm surge which coincided with the morning high tide resulting in water levels 5.5 m above chart datum. Combined with high waves, overtopping and breaching of dykes allowed flooding of low-lying areas behind the dykes. Approximately 150-200 residential properties were affected.

properties.name: Storms and Severe Thunderstorms : Gatineau QC
properties.description: Gatineau QC, April 23, 2007. Approximately 15,500 Hydro-QuÃ©bec customers were plunged into darkness in the Outaouais as a result of strong winds with gusts of up to 60km/h.

properties.name: Storms and Severe Thunderstorms : Fishing Lake SK
properties.description: Fishing Lake SK, May 25, 2007. An estimated 300 homes and cottages have been damaged by flooding from higher than normal snowfall and runoff at the lake, located two hours east of Saskatoon. The Fishing Lake area received 50 to 75mm of rain this week.

properties.name: Storms and Severe Thunderstorms : Vancouver Island BC
properties.description: Vancouver Island BC, December 20, 2006. About 25,000 homes and businesses on BC's South Coast lost power in the wake of another windstorm that blew through the area overnight.

properties.name: Storms and Severe Thunderstorms : Vancouver BC
properties.description: Vancouver BC, December 12, 2006. BC's south coast is being pounded by another windstorm, with at least 190,000 BC Hydro customers without electricity. The storm uprooted tress, knocked down power lines and disrupted travel with winds gusting at 100km/h in some places.

properties.name: Storms and Severe Thunderstorms : Maple Ridge BC
properties.description: Maple Ridge BC, March 12, 2007. Mudslides and flooding have hit BC's lower mainland after a weekend of heavy rain, leading to road closures and evacuation warnings. About 170 houses were flooded and hundreds of people have been told they may have to leave their homes, after the Alouette River spilled its banks.

properties.name: Storms and Severe Thunderstorms : Huntingdon QC
properties.description: Huntingdon QC, May 31, 2008. More than 95mm of rain fell on the city of Huntingdon, flooding most of its 1,300 homes and raising fears that the ChÃ¢teauguay River would overflow.

properties.name: Storms and Severe Thunderstorms : MontÃ©rÃ©gie and Eastern Townships QC
properties.description: MontÃ©rÃ©gie and Eastern Townships QC, June 10, 2008. Thousands of residents south of Montreal had their power knocked out as many regions were hit with wind gusts exceeding 100km/h.

properties.name: Storms and Severe Thunderstorms : Sainte-Anne-des-Plaines QC
properties.description: Sainte-Anne-des-Plaines QC, August 19, 2006. A small community located 50km north-east of Montreal was at the centre of a torrential downpour that produced 135mm of rain in less than three hours.

properties.name: Storms and Severe Thunderstorms : Saint John NB
properties.description: Saint John NB, February 14, 2008. A boil-water order was imposed following a rain storm that saw nearly 80mm of rain dumped on the city.

properties.name: Storms and Severe Thunderstorms : GaspÃ© QC
properties.description: GaspÃ© QC, August 15, 2007. 50 to 110mm of rain fell on the city in less than 10 hours.

properties.name: Storms and Severe Thunderstorms : Vancouver BC
properties.description: Vancouver BC, November 12, 2007. High winds battered southern BC, leaving more than 200,000 people without power and stranding thousands of airplane and ferry passengers.

properties.name: Storms and Severe Thunderstorms : Matane QC
properties.description: Matane QC, November 17, 2007. For the third time in four months, Eastern Quebec was hard hit by bad weather. This time, 275 people were evacuated, mainly from Matane and Saint-RenÃ©-de-Matane.

properties.name: Storms and Severe Thunderstorms : Eastern Quebec and Northwest New Brunswick
properties.description: Eastern Quebec and northwest New Brunswick, August 2, 2008. Storms and heavy rainfalls pounded the regions of Beauce, Temiscouata and GaspÃ©sie, in eastern Quebec, and neighbouring northwest New Brunswick. A deluge of more than 100mm of rain was suspected of drowning two and washing out dozens of roads.

properties.name: Storms and Severe Thunderstorms : Southern Ontario
properties.description: Southern Ontario, April 20-21, 2000.  The Windsor area registered 95 mm of rain in a 24-hour period and the storm dumped almost 70 mm of rain on the London area, Sarnia got 50 mm, while 40 mm fell on the Toronto area.  Sewers were backed up and roads washed out, and many short power outages occurred.  One child suffered injuries in Toronto due to violent winds, which gusted up to 80 km/h.

properties.name: Storms and Severe Thunderstorms : Ontario and Quebec
properties.description: Ontario and Quebec, October 29, 2006. A storm that blew in from the United States left about 49,000 Quebec and 30,000 Ontario residents without power. High winds felled lines in a broad band across central Ontario, while in Quebec, the Laurentians region, north on Montreal, and the Gasp were particularly hard hit.

properties.name: Storms and Severe Thunderstorms : Morley, Chapple, Dawson, Emo, Lake of the Woods, La Vallee, Rainy River, Fort Frances ON
properties.description: Morley, Chapple, Dawson, Emo, Lake of the Woods, La Vallee, Rainy River, Fort Frances ON, July 31, 2001.  A severe summer storm hit eight municipalities and two rural areas in northwestern Ontario.  These were declared disaster areas, and the damages were covered by the Ontario government.  Effects of the storm include fallen trees, washed out roads, tossed boats, and broken docks.

properties.name: Storms and Severe Thunderstorms : Edmonton AB
properties.description: Edmonton AB, July 11, 2004.  Severe hail and rain battered parts of Edmonton, causing extensive flooding of basements and streets, and forcing the evacuation of 30,000 people from the worlds largest shopping mall, the West Edmonton Mall.

properties.name: Storms and Severe Thunderstorms : Edmonton area AB
properties.description: Edmonton area AB, July 18, 2009.  A severe thunderstorm in the Edmonton area resulted in extremely strong winds that impacted the City of Edmonton, Lamont County, and Strathcona County, causing damage to municipal infrastructure, including fallen trees on roadways.

properties.name: Storms and Severe Thunderstorms : Yarmouth County NS
properties.description: Yarmouth County NS, November 8, 2010. A severe storm produced a total rainfall ranging from 140mm to 250mm.  At least 20 roads were closed due to flooding, and more than 100 people were evacuated from their homes.

properties.name: Storms and Severe Thunderstorms : Southwest Alberta
properties.description: Southwest Alberta, May 21 to 25, 2008.  A series of rainstorms and the resulting high stream flows significantly impacted municipalities in Southwestern Alberta.  The Government of Alberta established a Disaster Recovery Program on July 30, 2008, covering all affected municipalities and residents.  The program includes the municipalities of the Town of Black Diamond, Town of High River, Town of Okotoks, City of Clagary, Municipal District of Foothills, Kananaskis Improvement District, Municipal District of Pincher Creek, the Municipal District of Rocky View, and the Stony First Nation.

properties.name: Storms and Severe Thunderstorms : Nova Scotia and New Brunswick
properties.description: Nova Scotia and New Brunswick, October 26, 2009. A storm pushed through New Brunswick during the last week of October. Hydro utilities reported more than 6,000 customers without electricity in New Brunswick and about 2,000 in Nova Scotia before power was restored.  Some Moncton residents faced sewer backups after high winds caused leaves to fall, blocking catch basins. Several streets and homes flooded after 116 mm of rain fell in St. Johns. Firefighters responded to more than 30 calls for flooded basements filled with more than a metre of sewer water. October rainfall in Saint John amounted to 245.4 mm, which was just 2 mm less than the record set in 1977.

properties.name: Storms and Severe Thunderstorms : Winnipeg to Steinbach MB
properties.description: Winnipeg to Steinbach MB, August 14, 2009. Powerful thunderstorms, spectacular lightning strikes and baseball-sized hail hammered a wide area of southern Manitoba from Winnipeg to Steinbach. More than 1,100 motorists filed claims with Manitoba Public Insurance (MPI) by the next morning; losses ranged between $50 and $75 million. The storm also knocked out power to about 4,000 homes

properties.name: Storms and Severe Thunderstorms : North Battleford SK
properties.description: North Battleford SK, July 22, 2010.  A sudden and severe downpour of rain caused extensive flooding in the city of North Battleford.  A local state of emergency was declared.  97 homes were flooded and the Red Cross provided food and accommodations to 45 people from 11 families.

properties.name: Storms and Severe Thunderstorms : Meadow Lake to the South and Stony Rapids to the North, and between the Alberta border to the West and the Manitoba border to the East.
properties.description: Meadow Lake to the South and Stony Rapids to the North and between the Alberta border to the West and the Manitoba border to the East, June 23,2005.  An intense low pressure system caused heavy rainfall from July 23-25, 2005, affecting an area of northern Saskatchewan already saturated by snowmelt between Meadow Lake to the south and Stony Rapids to the north, and between the Alberta border to the west and the Manitoba border to the east.  The closure of Highway 905 due to flooding in several locations resulted in the disruption of services to northern communities, including Stony Rapids and Black Lake, until the road was re-opened on July 31, 2005.  Preliminary eligible costs were estimated at $3,200,000, which would result in a federal share of approximately $1,100,000.

properties.name: Storms and Severe Thunderstorms : Vancouver, Fraser Valley and the Greater Vancouver Regional Districts BC
properties.description: Vancouver, Fraser Valley and the Greater Vancouver Regional Districts BC, January 6 to 8, 2009. A severe rainstorm from January 6 to January 8 affected Vancouver, Fraser Valley and the Greater Vancouver Regional Districts causing overland flooding, mudslides and landslides until January 31.    Preliminary eligible costs are estimated at $16,500,000, which would result in a federal share of approximately $6,900,000.

properties.name: Storms and Severe Thunderstorms : Calgary, Edmonton, St. Albert, the town of Stony Plain, Parkland County, Two Hills County, Kneehill County, Camrose, and the municipal districts of Rocky View and Bighorn AB
properties.description: Calgary, Edmonton, St. Albert, the town of Stony Plain, Parkland County, Two Hills County, Kneehill County, Camrose, and the municipal districts of Rocky View and Bighorn AB, June 5, 2007. A severe rainstorm on June 5 affected the cities of Calgary, Edmonton, and St. Albert, the town of Stony Plain, Parkland County, the County of Two Hills, Kneehill County, Camrose, County , and the Municipal Districts of Rocky View and Bighorn.  Many residences and small businesses experienced flooding resulting in loss of contents and structural damage.  Infrastructure damage to municipal roads and storm sewer lines, and provincial parks also occurred.

properties.name: Storms and Severe Thunderstorms : Greater Vancouver and Fraser Valley BC
properties.description: Greater Vancouver and Fraser Valley BC, January 6 to 8, 2009. A severe rainstorm affected Vancouver, Fraser Valley and the greater Vancouver regional districts.

properties.name: Storms and Severe Thunderstorms : Lethbridge AB
properties.description: Lethbridge AB, July 1, 2008. More than 300 homes suffered damage in a flash flood caused by an intense rain storm.

properties.name: Storms and Severe Thunderstorms : South-East Alberta
properties.description: South-East Alberta, August 2, 2009. A powerful storm moved out of the Rocky foothills and tracked southeastward across the province with wind and hail that left a devastating path of destruction. The main hail zone scarped the extreme northeastern portion of Calgary. Inside the city, hail diameters reached baseball size and wind speeds peaked at 107 km/h. The storm left downed trees, broken windows and a swath of damage, knocking out power to several thousand customers. In some places, hail measured 10 cm deep. The nearby town of Carstairs was devastated by the battering large hail. Hail damage stretched from Olds to Bow Island and was 55 km wide in places.

properties.name: Storms and Severe Thunderstorms : Hamilton and Toronto ON
properties.description: Hamilton and Toronto ON, July 26, 2009. A storm cell stalled over the western end of Lake Ontario. Hamilton was hard hit. Waves of thunderstorms pounded the city, leaving citizens with flooded basements and motorists stuck in traffic caused by road closures. The midday downpour turned Red Hill Creek into an angry brown torrent that forced the closure of nearby roads and highways. Water gushed into 7,000 basements and power was shut off to thousands of customers. While the Hamilton Airport observed only 28 mm of rain, radar estimates confirmed rainfall amounts in an unofficial gauge totaling 109 mm in two hours - worse than a 100-year storm and one of the most intense short-duration rainfalls on record in Canada. Conditions were made worse because the ground was super-saturated from storms two days earlier. In Toronto, parts of Lakeshore Boulevard near the Exhibition grounds were submerged. To the north, a pair of giant sinkholes swallowed part of Finch Avenue West - big enough to hold a fleet of cars and deep enough to cover a four-storey building.

properties.name: Storms and Severe Thunderstorms : Ottawa, Toronto and Windsor ON
properties.description: Ottawa, Toronto and Windsor ON, April 25, 2009. A spate of fierce thunderstorms broke out across southwestern, southcentral and eastern Ontario. Winds at Toronto Pearson International Airport gusted to 115 km/h, the strongest wind gust reported since January 1978. Power lines and trees came down across the province, knocking out power to 100,000 customers.  Embedded in the thunderstorm cluster were marble-sized hail near Parry Sound, waterspouts in the Ottawa River, straight-line winds and weak tornados in Windsor and Ottawa. In Windsor, the roof was ripped off a union hall building with chunks of roofing and shards of glass littering the lawn and front steps. At Ottawa's Rockcliffe Flying Club, winds damaged 18 planes. Both tornados were F0 in intensity with winds of up to 110 km/h.

properties.name: Storms and Severe Thunderstorms : Lorette River, Quebec City QC
properties.description: Lorette River, Quebec City QC, September 26, 2005.  The remnants of hurricane Rita caused flooding by overflowing the Lorette River.  108.55mm of rain fell.

properties.name: Storms and Severe Thunderstorms : Regina SK
properties.description: Regina SK, July 22, 2008. Wicked weather wreaked havoc acress Regina, with wind gusts up to 92km/h and 11.2mm of rain. The squall left about 5,000 customers in parts of north and east Regina without power.

properties.name: Storms and Severe Thunderstorms : La Tuque QC
properties.description: La Tuque QC, July 22, 2008. Strong flooding caused by torrential rains forced the evacuation of at least 112 people and caused considerable damage to a number of homes, two of which will likely need to be demolished.

properties.name: Storms and Severe Thunderstorms : Kingston ON
properties.description: Kingston ON, September 15, 2008. An overnight wind and rainstorm walloped Kingston, cut power to thousands of homes in the area, knocked one ferry out of service and toppled small buildings.

properties.name: Storms and Severe Thunderstorms : Colchester, Pictou, Antigonish, Inverness, Victoria, Cumberland and Halifax NS
properties.description: Colchester, Pictou, Antigonish, Inverness, Victoria, Cumberland and Halifax NS, August 29 to 31, 2008. A low pressure system moved into Nova Scotia, bringing heavy rains up to 49 mm.  The same system returned on August 31 and brought even more rain up to 68 mm.  The total rainfall over the three day period caused flooding.

properties.name: Storms and Severe Thunderstorms : West of Gander, East to Hare Bay, South to Swift Current NL
properties.description: West of Gander, East to Hare Bay, South to Swift Current NL, July 30, 2008. A weather system, beginning west of the town of Gander extending east to Hare Bay, and south to Swift Current, caused severe thunderstorms and heavy rain.  This resulted in damage to private property and provincial infrastructure.

properties.name: Storms and Severe Thunderstorms : Queens County PE
properties.description: Queens County PE, September 6 and 7, 2008. Storm Hanna caused heavy rainfall, resulting in infrastructure damage mainly in Queens County, with major highway damage to the Trans-Canada Highway in Cornwall.

properties.name: Storms and Severe Thunderstorms : Halifax and Lunenburg NS
properties.description: Halifax and Lunenburg NS, November 3, 2007. Storm Noel.  The province was subjected to a severe storm throughout the province, with the heaviest impact in the areas of Halifax and Lunenburg.

properties.name: Storms and Severe Thunderstorms : Peninsulas of Avalon, Burin and Bonavista NL
properties.description: Avalon, Burin and Bonavista peninsulas NL, August 1, 2007.  Storm Chantal.  A severe rainstorm resulted in damage to private property and provincial and local government infrastructure.

properties.name: Storms and Severe Thunderstorms : Municipalities of Pipestone, Sifton, Cameron, White water, Morton, Riverside, Turtle Mountain, Strathcona and Argyle and the Whiteshell Provincial Park MB
properties.description: Municipalities of Pipestone, Sifton, Cameron, White water, Morton, Riverside, Turtle Mountain, Strathcona and Argyle and the Whiteshell Provincial Park MB, June 22 to 24 June, 2007.  Wind storms and tornados caused significant damages.

properties.name: Winter Storm : Quebec
properties.description: Quebec, January 9, 2008. A vigorous cold front brought very strong winds that generated power outages in several regions of Quebec. A total of 83,000 Hydro-Quebec customers across the province were left without electricity.

properties.name: Winter Storm : Lambton County ON
properties.description: Lambton County ON, December 13, 2010. A severe winter storm caused the closure of Highway 402 in Lambton County.  The Canadian Forces assisted the Ontario Provincial Police in rescuing 237 motorists who were stranded in their vehicles.  One officer received a minor injury while trying to reach stranded motorists and one man was later found dead due to exposure to the elements.

properties.name: Winter Storm : Maritimes provinces
properties.description: Maritimes provinces, December 4, 2007. A powerful storm that dumped up to 40cm of wet, heavy snow on parts of Atlantic Canada knocked out power in all four provinces leaving approximately 50,000 people without electricity.

properties.name: Winter Storm : Wolfe Lake and Moncton NB
properties.description: Wolfe Lake and Moncton NB, February 2, 2003. Ice storms resulted in 40-60 mm of frozen rain coating the region and at Wolfe Lake, 58.3 mm of freezing rain was recorded as falling. Winds reached 75 km/hr generating a wind chill of minus 27 degrees centigrade.  Schools closed for one week.  More than 63,000 residences were left without power and phone services due to the downed power lines, which were a direct result of the weight of freezing rain atop the infrastructure. There were a huge number of livestock fatalities, extensive damages to barns and silos, and maple sugar wood lots were damaged.

properties.name: Winter Storm : Prince Edward Island
properties.description: Prince Edward Island, December 13, 2008.
