An ice storm on December 13, 2008 felled 300 utility poles resulting in one of the worst power outages since the mid-1970s and cost Maritime Electric approximately $1.5 million to repair.  Nearly 95 per cent of Islanders were without electricity, as freezing rain and ice pellet-drizzle mix left thick layers of ice on roof tops, trees and transmission lines.  Power poles were pulled down by ice-laden lines and strong winds.  Across the province, makeshift shelters were organized in legion halls, fire stations, schools and community centres. Rescue teams and hydro crews arrived from outside the province to assist. The Canadian military also remained on standby at the Canadian Forces Base in Gagetown, NB.

properties.name: Winter Storm : Nova Scotia
properties.description: Nova Scotia, February 18-20, 2004. A snowstorm known as "White Juan" hit the Maritimes resulting in record-breaking snowfall. On February 19, Halifax surpassed and almost doubled its previous snowfall record when the city received 88.5 cm. A four-day state of emergency was in place as well as a nine-hour curfew for three nights (except for essential workers). Thousands were left without power.

properties.name: Winter Storm : Prince Edward Island
properties.description: Prince Edward Island, March 31, 2003.  Both freezing rain and heavy snowfall destroyed power lines in the province. Power losses were experienced in western PEI. The province also experienced flooding as a result of heavy rainfall that contributed to the spring runoff. See Nova Scotia and Newfoundland entries for more information on this event.

properties.name: Winter Storm : Quebec
properties.description: Quebec, February 10, 2001. Freezing rain, heavy snow and wind caused road accidents and homelessness. Six died in weather-related motor vehicle accidents.

properties.name: Winter Storm : Maritimes provinces
properties.description: Maritimes provinces, January 17-22, 2000.  An intense storm hit the maritimes for 6 days. Up to 70 centimetres of snow fell in some areas and temperatures plummeted to Ã‚â€“40 degrees Centigrade with the wind chill.  Flooding caused extensive damage to private property and public infrastructure in Newfoundland, New Brunswick, and P.E.I. Wind gusts hit 120 kilometres per hour.  Cape Breton, Shediac, New Brunswick and P.E.I were hit especially hard by the storm, as well as areas along the Gulf of St. Laurence and the Northumberland Strait in New Brunswick.

properties.name: Winter Storm : Prince Edward Island
properties.description: Prince Edward Island, January 28, 2008. An ice storm knocked out electricity to more than 20,000 customers, mostly in central and western parts of the province.

properties.name: Winter Storm : New Brunswick
properties.description: New Brunswick, March 21, 2008. Freezing rain and ice flattened trees in New Brunswick leaving some 6,000 residents without electricity.

properties.name: Winter Storm : Fishing Lake SK
properties.description: Fishing Lake SK, April 28, 2007. An Estimated 300 homes and cabins have been damaged by flooding from higher than average snowfall and runoff at Fishing Lake.

properties.name: Winter Storm : Russell ON
properties.description: Russell ON, December 1-2, 2006.  A major blackout, caused by a freezing rain storm, left virtually the entire town without electricity. The mayor declared a state of emergency, which lasted for several days.

properties.name: Winter Storm : Newfoundland
properties.description: Newfoundland, March 30-31, 2005. Heavy snow affected most of Newfoundland (excluding Labrador) while the Avalon and Burin peninsulas experienced rain. Gander saw 62 cm of snow and Grand Falls-Windsor was hit by 60 cm in one day. The Burin community of Salt Pond was plagued by over 150 mm of rain, St.Lawrence by over 80 mm, and St.John's saw 60 mm of rain. Bonavista Bay and Hare Bay were also affected.

properties.name: Tornado : Elie MB
properties.description: Elie MB, June 22, 2007. Tornadoes touched down west of Winnipeg in Eli and near Oakville, ripping apart several homes and flipping over a semi-trailer on the Trans-Canada Highway. Miraculously, no one appears to have been seriously hurt.

properties.name: Tornado : LanaudiÃ¨re QC
properties.description: LanaudiÃ¨re QC, June 29, 2008. A tornado, with winds at times reaching 120km/h and producing hail the size of golf balls, caused a great deal of property damage. Nearly 15,000 homes were left without power.

properties.name: Tornado : Winnipeg MB
properties.description: Winnipeg MB, July 11, 2008. Wind caused havoc across Winnipeg and eastern Manitoba, including one area that may have been hit by a tornado. Up to 5,000 homes lost power in total.

properties.name: Tornado : Pine Lake AB
properties.description: Pine Lake AB, July 14, 2000.  A tornado hit Pine Lake at 300 kilometres an hour, killing 12 people and injuring more than 140.  Close to one-thousand people were displaced from a campsite as their recreational vehicles were damaged.

properties.name: Tornado : Grande Prairie AB
properties.description: Grande Prairie AB, July 8, 2004.  A tornado swept through Grand Prairie, snapping hydro poles and tearing shingles from buildings.

properties.name: Tornado : Goderich ON
properties.description: Goderich ON, August 21-22, 2011. At approximately 16:00 EDT, a Fujita Scale Three (F3: winds near 250 km/hr) tornado touched down in the town of Goderich, ON causing extensive damages including damaged roof tops, fallen trees, gas leaks and hydroelectricity outages. Natural gas was off to 90% for the town of Goderich as well as to residents in the surrounding municipalities. As of 10:30 EDT on August 22, 2011, power had been restored to most of the afffected area.

properties.name: Tornado : DÃ©lÃ©age to Mont-Laurier
properties.description: DÃ©lÃ©age to Mont-Laurier, August 4, 2009. The season's most powerful tornado occurred along a track from DÃ©lÃ©age, through Aumond, to Mont-Laurier in the upper Laurentians. It blew away roofs, pushed over walls, tossed cars around, snapped utility poles and downed power lines leaving 4,000 without power. Among the 40 damaged homes in Mont-Laurier, 28 were rendered uninhabitable. There were no serious injuries. The tornado caused about $6 million in insured losses. The tornado's path through Mont-Laurier was 300 m wide, but its 40-km track was an unusually long distance for a tornado in Quebec and a strong indication of the storm's severity. The last time a stronger tornado touched down in the province was on the same day in 1994 when an F3 tornado destroyed more than 400 homes in Aylmer.

properties.name: Tornado : Kawacatoose First Nation SK
properties.description: Kawacatoose First Nation SK, July 2, 2010.  An F3 tornado ripped through the Kawacatoose First Nation, destroying 15 homes and causing $2.3 million in damages.

properties.name: Tornado : Midland ON
properties.description: Midland ON, June 23, 2010.  An F2 tornado destroyed approximately 50 homes and caused damages estimated to be $15 million.  The F2 classification means that wind speeds between 180 and 240 kilometres per hour were reached.  12 people were reported to be injured.  Ontario provided immediate provincial assistance of up to $1 million to aid in cleanup and repairs.

properties.name: Tornado : Leamington ON
properties.description: Leamington ON, June 6, 2010. A strong thunderstorm cell moved over the southern portions of Essex County. It spawned 4 tornadoes and a series of damaging wind gusts along an intermittent path of damage about 40 kilometres in length. The most significant damage was done by an F2 tornado which swept through the south end of the town of Leamington, with peak winds between 180 and 240 km/h.  Approximately 4,500 hydro customers were left without power, and 12 homes were deemed unsafe due to damages.  The Red Cross provided an emergency shelter to help in the wake of the disaster.

properties.name: Tornado : Toronto, Windsor, Vaughan and Newmarket ON
properties.description: Toronto, Windsor, Vaughan and Newmarket ON, August 20, 2009.  A supercell storm developed just south of Lake Huron and tracked northeastward for a remarkable 200 km. The heat and humidity hanging over Ontario increased once the clouds disappeared.  At the same time, a squall line developed over Lower Michigan and traveled across Ontario. This system produced straight-line winds from Windsor to northeast of Toronto and destructive tornados in Vaughan and Newmarket. While these tornados were wreaking havoc just north of Toronto, another series of supercell thunderstorms was spawning tornados in portions of Simcoe County, Muskoka and Parry Sound Districts to the east of Georgian Bay, and north towards Lake Nipissing. In total, the day's weather produced 19 confirmed tornadoes, including: four F0, eleven F1, and four F2. That was the greatest number of F2 tornadoes in Ontario in one day since the Barrie/Central Ontario tornadoes of May 31, 1985. It was also a new Canadian record for the most confirmed tornadoes in one day. Violent winds snapped trees, lifted roofs, flattened cars, mowed down fences, collapsed farm buildings, and inflicted property losses around $100 million. The first tornado of the day touched down in the town of Durham in Grey County, killing an 11-year-old boy as he left a nearby conservation area day camp.  About 600 homes, mostly in the communities of Maple and Woodbridge, were damaged. Thirty-eight were demolished and declared unsafe. Major flooding occurred along the lakeshore, and at the peak of the storm Hydro One reported that 69,000 customers had lost power.

properties.name: Vehicle : Rogers Pass BC
properties.description: Rogers Pass BC, November 27, 2000.  A bus carrying tourists from Taiwan crashed head-on with a transport truck in a tunnel on the Trans-Canada Highway, killing six and injuring 21.  The accident happened in the 316-metre Lanark snowshed tunnel, closing the highway for about 14 hours.  The transport truck was empty at the time of the accident.

properties.name: Wildfire : Northwest Ontario
properties.description: Northwest Ontario, May 13, 2007. Up to 300 people have been forced from their cottages in an area about 75kms west of Thunder Bay, where the biggest fire - Thunder Bay 37 - had raged through about 11,500 hectares.

properties.name: Wildfire : Northern Alberta and Conklin
properties.description: Northern AB and Conklin, May 14 - June 7, 2002. The House River Fire was first spotted on May 17, 2002. It burned 248,243 hectares. The fire was approximately 100 km north of Lac La Biche. At its peak, 1,000 firefighters were on the fireline. The task was difficult given the strong and shifting winds and minimal precipitation. The fire perimeter was secured by June 7, 2002. This was Alberta's second largest forest fire since 1961. On May 27 the Regional Municipality of Wood Buffalo evacuated approximately 1,550 people. There were approximately 1,300 from work camps, and 250 from the community of Conklin. All individuals were allowed to return on June 8, 2002.

properties.name: Wildfire : Montreal Lake SK
properties.description: Montreal Lake SK, May 20-22, 2002.  Extreme burning conditions existed throughout Saskatchewan at this time.  Winds gusting at 50 to 60 km/h aided the spread of fires (around 48 in total), mostly in grasses and brush.  This specific fire was first spotted around the Bittern Lake area and was moving north towards the eastern part of the community of Montreal Lake.  Approximately 130 evacuees from this community and the Montreal Lake Cree Nation were moved to Prince Albert.

properties.name: Wildfire : Peerless Lake, Trout Lake AB
properties.description: Peerless Lake and Trout Lake AB, June 23, 2002.  The Peerless Lake Complex involved three separate fires within a small area approximately 155 km north of Slave Lake. These three fires forced the MD of Opportunity No. 17 to evacuate approximately 600 people to Red Earth.  The wild fires consumed a total of 15,438 ha of forest.

properties.name: Wildfire : Turnor Lake SK
properties.description: Turnor Lake SK, June 25, 2002. Three hundred and fifty residents of Turnor Lake, located 600 km northwest of Saskatoon, were evacuated to nearby towns. The fire was charged by exceptionally dry and hot weather, and winds pushed the fire towards Turnor Lake. Water bombers continuously dropped their payload on the fire, while the town buildings and trees were showered by industrial sprinkler systems.

properties.name: Wildfire : Hawes/Patuanak SK
properties.description: Hawes/Patuanak SK, June 28-30, 2002. One hundred three evacuated.

properties.name: Wildfire : Crutwell, Dillon, Hatchett Lake, Pelican Narrows, Deschambeault, Wahpeton First Nation, Nordell, Peter Pond SK
properties.description: Crutwell, Dillon, Hatchett Lake, Pelican Narrows, Deschambeault, Wahpeton First Nation, Nordell, Peter Pond SK, June 28 - July 1, 2002. Five hundred six evacuated.

properties.name: Wildfire : Nemiscau region, near James Bay QC
properties.description: Nemiscau region, near James Bay QC, July 2, 2002. Of 50 forest fires burning in Quebec around this time, the Nemiscau fire was the most noticeable.  The fire travelled within 800 metres of the native village of Nemaska. A total of 630 Chisasibi and Nemiscau-region residents were evacuated. The fire was ignited by intense thunder and lightning storms and destroyed over 600 km2 of forest. Consequently, 6000 Quebec forestry workers were laid-off. Hydro-Quebec disconnected its service to 500 000 people given the proximity of the fire to a major power line. Smoke could be seen in most of Quebec, parts of Ontario, and the northeastern United States.

properties.name: Wildfire : Near community of Sheshatshui and town of North West River NL
properties.description: Near the community of Sheshatshui and the Town of North West River NL, July 3, 2002.  A forest fire ignited 10-12 km from the community of Sheshatshui and the Town of North West River. Approximately 1200 residents were evacuated to the town of Happy Valley-Goose Bay. The fire burned 3km2 of forest.

properties.name: Wildfire : Chisasibi QC
properties.description: Chisasibi QC, May 29, 2005. Forest fire forced about 600 people in the Cree community of Chisasibi to be evacuated to the nearby village of Radisson.  The fire was human caused, and was started within 1 km of the town.  Evacuees were able to return to their homes by May 30.

properties.name: Wildfire : Kee-Way-Win FN; Townships of Terrace Bay and Schrieber; Village of Rossport; Pays Plat FN; Deer Lake FN, ON
properties.description: Kee-Way-Win FN; Townships of Terrace Bay and Schrieber; Village of Rossport; Pays Plat FN; Deer Lake FN, ON, July 2002. Members of several communities were concerned by nearby fires and smoke. More than 1000 people were evacuated to Thunder Bay, Geraldton and Sioux Lookout. Municipal emergency declarations occurred in six communities.

properties.name: Wildfire : Manitoba
properties.description: Manitoba, April to October 2003. The province of Manitoba experienced 1,148 wildfires during the 2003 season. While the fires actually began at the end of March,  damages began to affect communities in April. The Thompson area was particularly affected. A lightening strike near Thompson began a forest fire that was sustained through hot and dry weather. Approximately 900 people were evacuated, many from aboriginal comunities including: 250 people from Red Sucker Lake First Nation and 92 people from God's River First Nation were evacuated due to fires that began in July. In August, approximately 155 people were evacuated from Shamattawa while 250 were evacuated from Split Lake.

properties.name: Wildfire : Eastern Passage, Cole Harbour NS
properties.description: Cole Harbour, Eastern Passage NS, May 19, 2003.  A forest fire started in a bog near Cole Harbour.  High winds and dry conditions helped the fire spread out of control burning 240 hectares and forcing the evacuation of 240 homes.  Approximately 500 people were evacuated near Eastern Passage in northeast of Halifax.  No damage or injuries reported.

properties.name: Wildfire : Southeastern British Columbia and Southwestern Alberta
properties.description: Southeastern British Columbia and Southwestern Alberta; July and August 2003.  Dozens of communities were evacuated due to wildfires started by lightning and careless fire use.  Over 50,000 people were evacuated and firefighting costs alone are estimated at $400 million dollars.

properties.name: Wildfire : Norman Wells NT
properties.description: Norman Wells, NT, July 21, 2003. Lightening started a fire in an on old-growth black spruce forest approximately 17 km from Norman Wells. The fire was sustained by high temperatures and gusting winds. Norman Wells declared a state of emergency. About 100 people were evacuated due to thick smoke. Those with respiratory problems, the elderly, and the young were evacuated by plane to Inuvik while others were sent to nearby communities via boat.

properties.name: Wildfire : Deschambault Lake SK
properties.description: Deschambault Lake SK, July 1, 2008. Smoke from forest fires forced Deschambault Lake residents from their homes.

properties.name: Wildfire : Northern Saskatchewan
properties.description: Northern Saskatchewan, June 30, 2008. Some 2,000 people from the communities of Sandy Bay, Stony Rapids, Pelican Narrows, Black Lake and Uranium City in Saskatchewan's far north have been forced out of their homes due to 64 forest fires.

properties.name: Wildfire : Halifax NS
properties.description: Halifax NS, June 13, 2008. An unforeseen brush fire ravaged a wooded area east of Halifax. The fire destroyed two homes and forced 5,000 residents to evacuate their homes.

properties.name: Wildfire : Newbrook AB
properties.description: Newbrook AB, May 16, 2008. A forest fire that was raging north of Edmonton destroyed two homes and forced more than 150 people from their homes.

properties.name: Wildfire : Pukatawagan MB
properties.description: Pukatawagan MB, June 10, 2008. A town in northern Manitoba has declared a state of emergency as food and other necessities dwindle because of a burned-out railway bridge. More than 2,600 people in Pukatawagan, located about 900kms northwest of Winnipeg, are facing shortages of food and baby products.

properties.name: Wildfire : Norway House and Sherridon MB
properties.description: Norway House and Sherridon MB, May 28, 2008. A forest fire, that stretches from a point to the south of Lynn Lake in the northwest corner of the province south to Norway House Cree Nation and east to the Island Lake First Nations, has forced as many as 3,330 people out of their homes.

properties.name: Wildfire : South Indian Lake MB
properties.description: South Indian Lake MB, July 20, 2007. A forest fire just 16kms south of the South Indian Lake reserve had grown to more than 60,000 hectares in size, blanketing the community of 1,100 people in heavy smoke.

properties.name: Wildfire : Kootenay BC
properties.description: Kootenay BC, August 1, 2007. Forest fires raging in southeastern BC triggered a state of local emergency and caused three homes to be evacuated and power to be cut to more than 3,000 homes.

properties.name: Wildfire : Natuashish NL
properties.description: Natuashish NL, August 3, 2007. A forest fire was accidentally caused by a group of swimmers. The fire destroyed over 200 hectares of forest and forced the evacuation of 600 residents.

properties.name: Wildfire : Happy Valley - Goose Bay NL
properties.description: Happy Valley - Goose Bay NL, June 17, 2007.  A forest fire in Happy Valley - Goose Bay forced the evacuation of 200 homes.

properties.name: Wildfire : Chibougamau, James Bay QC
properties.description: Chibougamau, James Bay QC, June 6, 2005.  In Northern QuÃ©bec a forest fire near Chibougamau forced the evacuation of approximately 200 residents.  Approximately 650 Hydro-Quebec workers were airlifted in an evacuation operation in the James Bay area due to another forest fire. There were 57 active forest fires in Quebec at the time.  Forest fires have destroyed approximately 170,000 hectares of forest in Quebec this year.

properties.name: Wildfire : Kelowna BC
properties.description: Kelowna  BC, August 28, 2005.  A 25-hectare forest fire was reported in Rose Valley near Kelowna BC.  Approximately 75 homes in the subdivision were evacuated and about 528 people registered with emergency social services after the evacuation order.  No injuries or casualties were reported.

properties.name: Wildfire : Mistissini QC
properties.description: Mistissini QC, June 16, 2006. Residents of a Cree reserve were evacuated from their homes for the second time in as many weeks as a forest fire once again threatened their community.

properties.name: Wildfire : Tumbler Ridge BC
properties.description: Tumbler Ridge BC, July 3, 2006. Four thousand residents were ordered to vacate their homes as a forest fire came close enough to threaten the coal mining town.

properties.name: Wildfire : Nordegg AB
properties.description: Nordegg AB, July 4, 2006. About 130 residents, and dozens of campers, were forced to leave Nordegg after a forest fire came within 2kms of the village.

properties.name: Wildfire : Cariboo-Chilcotin BC
properties.description: Cariboo-Chilcotin BC, July 6, 2006. About 600 people living in remote communities in BC's Cariboo-Chilcotin region have been forced from their homes by the threat of two massive wildfires.

properties.name: Wildfire : Northwest Ontario
properties.description: Northwest Ontario, May 13, 2007. Up to 300 people have been forced from their cottages in an area about 75kms west of Thunder Bay, where the biggest fire - Thunder Bay 37 - had raged through about 11,500 hectares.

properties.name: Wildfire : Sept-ÃŽles QC
properties.description: Sept-ÃŽles QC, May 27, 2007. A major forest fire is raging over 11,000 hectares in the Abitibi region, about 530kms northwest of Montreal, forcing the removal of 1,500 residents.

properties.name: Wildfire : Wemotaci reserve and La Tuque QC
properties.description: Wemotaci reserve and La Tuque QC, May 23, 2010.   A 39 hectare fire forced the evacuation of 1,300 residents from the Wemotaci reserve.  This was just one of over 50 fires throughout the province that raged for weeks, resulting in large amounts of smoke leading to a smog alert for Montreal, Vaudreuil, Soulanges, Huntingdon, Richelieu Valley, St. Hyacinthe, Lachute, St. Jerome, Lanaudiere, Mauricie, Drummondville, and Bois-Franc.

properties.name: Wildfire : Kelowna, Kamloops and Cariboo BC
properties.description: Kelowna, Kamloops and Cariboo BC, July 18, 2009.  Fire season 2009 had 3,049 fires, 213 of which were wildland-urban interface fires. On July 18, fires broke out in the Glenrosa and Rose Valley communities of West Kelowna, combined with the Terrace Mountain fire west of Fintry, which led to multiple evacuation orders and alerts. July also saw an abundance of lightning storms leading to other fires of note throughout the province. Temperatures continued to break record highs and little precipitation was received in most areas. As September began, all personnel continued to work hard to contain fires across the Kamloops and Cariboo regions. The Lava Canyon fire, the largest, was nearly 55,000 hectares and growing.  There were over 100 notable fires during this fire season: at least 27 caused evacuation orders and at least a dozen more caused evacuation alerts.  Approximately 20,000 people were evacuated. One helicopter pilot lost his life in the line of duty.

properties.name: Wildfire : Williams Lake, Chilcotin, Houston, Burns Lake and Fraser Lake BC
properties.description: Williams Lake, Chilcotin, Houston, Burns Lake and Fraser Lake BC, July to September 2010.  Due to little precipitation and lightning strikes, from July 28 to July 31, the number of fires in British Columbia went from 600 to 1,100.  On August 18, a significant wind blew through the interior causing substantial growth of the fires.  All evacuation orders and alerts were removed by the first week of September.  Approximately 330,000 hectares burned due to 1,673 fires.  Over 1,400 personnel from out-of-province assisted with fighting the fires.  Two airtanker pilots died when their plane crashed.  Both the city of Vancouver and the Government of Alberta issued air quality warnings due to smoke caused by the fires.

properties.name: Wildfire : County of Thorhild AB
properties.description: County of Thorhild AB, May 12, 2010. A wildfire in the county of Thorhild, north of Edmonton, affected thousands of acres of land.  The community of Opal experienced numerous evacuation orders, up to 100 homes on May 17. The Province of Alberta provided $10 million in funding under the Municipal Wildfire Assistance Program to aid in the community's recovery.

properties.name: Wildfire : Chapleau ON
properties.description: Chapleau ON, May 27, 2010. A forest fire, which started in the Chapleau area near Wawa, burned through approximately 22 hydro poles and caused a power outage affecting approximately 2,000 local residents.

properties.name: Wildfire : 13km East of Cranberry Portage MB
properties.description: 13km East of Cranberry Portage MB, June 15, 2010. A fire approximately 13 km east of Cranberry Portage grew to approximately 55,000 hectares in size.  Residents from Cranberry Portage were advised to evacuate and the road to Sherridon was temporary closed to all but local traffic.

properties.name: Wildfire : Mishkeegogamang Ojibway First Nation (New Osnaburgh), Northern ON
properties.description: Mishkeegogamang Ojibway First Nation (New Osnaburgh), northern Ontario, June 22 to 27, 2011.  A state of emergency was declared as the First Nation community was overcome by smoke from more than 17 wildfires burning within 10 km of the community's housing area. The fire was estimated to be 37,000 hectares in size and not under control. 423 residents were evacuated between June 22 and June 24. Sioux Lookout, Greenstone (Gerldton) and Ignace declared States of Emergency as host communities. 10 MNR crews worked to bring fires under control while DND assisted with evacuations, and Health Canada assisted with medical services.

properties.name: Wildfire : Northern Ontario
properties.description: Northern Ontario, July 6 to 23, 2011. A series of  forest fires was sparked by a lightening storm on July 6, 2011. Fire personnel were not able to get the fires under control, and they quickly spread across Northern Ontario. 121 wildfires were reported as of July 20. Evacuation orders were put in place for communities in direct threat from fires as well as those communities suffering the combining impacts of smoke, power outages, food shortages and a lack of food storage capactity (many communities are only accessible by air). The following evacuations occurred: 535 people from Deer Lake First Nations (FN), 260 people from Cat Lake FN, 50 people from Mishkeegogamang FN, 280 people from Eabametoong FN (Fort Hope), 197 people from Keewaywin FN, approximately 1000 people from Kingfisher Lake FN, approximately 770 people from Sandy Lake FN, approximately 200 people from North Spirit Lake, and the entire communities of Keewaywin FN and Koocheching FN have been completely evacuated.   The wildfire has severly damaged more than 86 hydro poles and over 13 km of hydro lines, resulting in power outages across the northern region.

properties.name: Wildfire : Towns of Slave Lake, High Prairie, Little Buffalo, Lesser Slave Lake, Municipal Districts of Lesser Slave River, Red Earth Creek, and Loon Lake Whitefish Atikameg, and Woodland Cree First Nations AB
properties.description: Towns of Slave Lake, High Prairie, Little Buffalo, Lesser Slave Lake, Municipal Districts of Lesser Slave River, Red Earth Creek, and Loon Lake Whitefish Atikameg, and Woodland Cree First Nations AB, May 1, 2011 to May 21, 2011. 49 wildfires, beginning in the Slave Lake region of northern Alberta, spread prompting a forced evacuation. Penn West Petroleum, Exall Energy Corp., and Canadian Natural Resources Ltd. Halted drilling in the region, suspended production, and evacuated their employees. Canadian National (CN) Railway also halted their services in the region. As of May 16, 2011, more than 1,300 people had been evacuated from the area, and as wildfires continued to spread the number of evacuees rose to approximately 12,055 by May 19, 2011.

properties.name: Wildfire : Hall Lake SK
properties.description: Hall Lake SK, June 12 to 14, 2011. On June 12, 2011, the Saskatchewan Emergency Management Organization reported a 25 to 40 hectare wildfire burning approximately 3 to 4 kms from the La Ronge First Nation subcommunity of Hall Lake. 440 residents were evacuated. As of June 14, the wildfire was no longer considered to be a direct threat to residents, and the evacuation order was lifted.

properties.name: Derailment Release : Bellefleur NB
properties.description: Bellefleur NB, May 10, 2007. A freight train derailment occured near Bellefleur, NB, approximately 15km north-west of Grand Falls, adjacent to the St. John River. Of the 36 rail cars that went off the tracks, five cars contained hazardous, flammable materials; a 1.6km evacuation radius was consequently ordered.

properties.name: Derailment Release : Estevan SK
properties.description: Estevan SK, August 10, 2004.  Six tank cars of a Canadian Pacific freight train were derailed and three containing anhydrous ammonia wee overturned.  An evacuation order was issued and approximately 150 people were evacuated from the immediate area in Estevan.  There were no injuries or immediate threat to life or property.

properties.name: Fire : Boisbriand QC
properties.description: Boisbriand QC, August 15, 2006. Employees of Les RevÃªtements Polyval and workers from about ten surrounding factories as well as some residents were evacuated. Toxic chemicals, such as solvents and paints, helped fuel the flames.

properties.name: Fire : Amherstburg ON
properties.description: Amherstburg ON, August 15, 2006. A huge fire at a plastics recycling plant forced hundreds of resiadents to flee their homes. Smoke was 20 meters high over the area and grew to roughly the size of two football fields.

properties.name: Fire : Zama City AB
properties.description: Zama City AB, August 15, 2008. A block of sulphur caught fire emitting deadly hydrogen-sulphide gas and causing the nearby town to be evacuated.

properties.name: Leak / Spill Release : Glovertown NL
properties.description: Glovertown NL, December 13, 2005.  A massive propane leak in a boat-building facility in Glovertown forced more than 250 people to evacuate their homes included 50 seniors living in a nursing home only metres away from the yard.

properties.name: Leak / Spill Release : Abbotsford BC
properties.description: Abbotsford BC, September 28, 2005. A fuel-tanker truck containing 38,000 litres of a gasoline-diesel mix overturned in Abbotsford, BC.  Approximately 700 homes, three schools and several businesses were affected and about 4,000 were evacuated. Fuel from the spill contaminated a creek and killed unknown number of fish.  Electric supply was shut off to the area as a precautionary measure.  No injuries or fatalities were reported.  City crews flushed the storm sewer system with water to dilute the fuel and evacuees were allowed to return home.

properties.name: Leak / Spill Release : Dartmouth NS
properties.description: Dartmouth NS, July 5, 2007. Approximately 1000 people were evacuated from Burnside Industrial Park due to a propane leak.

properties.name: Leak / Spill Release : Dryden ON
properties.description: Dryden ON, July 30, 2002. A chlorine dioxide leak at a nearby paper mill caused 300 to 400 people to be evacuated from the immediate downwind area.

properties.name: Leak / Spill Release : Chetwynd BC
properties.description: Chetwynd BC, August 1, 2000.  An oil pipeline break released approximately 1 million litres of crude oil into the Pine River, causing extensive fish kill in the Pine River.  The wells that supply drinking water to some of the farms located along the river have been contaminated.  The Pine River water intake was turned off to avoid potential water system contamination.
